questions.answer_description:
Box 1: No -
SAP HANA Replication consists of one primary node and at least one secondary node. Changes to the data on the primary node are replicated to the secondary node synchronously or asynchronously.

Box 2: No -
Since SPS11 SAP HANA system replication can be run in two different operation modes:
✑ delta_datashipping
✑ logreplay

Box 3: Yes -
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/sap-hana-high-availability-rhel https://blogs.sap.com/2018/01/08/your-sap-on-azure-part-4-high-availability-for-sap-hana-using-system-replication/

comments.content: Azure AD application is required for the STONITH using azure fencing agent, to shut down VMs and prevent splitbrain. Using the fencing agent instead of using a VM as iSCSI STONITH device is to meet the business requirements to - minimize costs whenever possible.
Is STONITH used for disaster recovery?

discussion.content:
Option A - No. Sync mode is mostly used for High Availability, also recommended when the nodes are within 100Kms distance.
Option B - Must be No. Operation modes must be identical between nodes in a Multi node replication and there is nothing mentioned in the question about the modes.
Option C - ? Azure AD application for failover, not sure about this.
Answers should be all No. 3rd question should be No (as AD has nothing to do with failover, it is for network authentication)
i think N/Y/Y

Option B, NO is correct.
Minimize the bandwidth used for database synchronization.
https://help.sap.com/viewer/6b94445c94ae495c83a19646e7c3fd56/2.0.03/en-US/627bd11e86c84ec2b9fcdf585d24011c.html
first box is indeed No, although case study indicates that they need minimal downtime, across regions, from on-prem to Azure scenarios only support asyc replication ( more than 100 kms)

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are planning replication of the SAP HANA database for the disaster recovery environment in Azure.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Pi - cpu

comments.content: Yes, PI license it´s affected by CPU increase.

discussion.content:
Answer: A. SAP ECC

Explanation:
Changing the size of the virtual machines can affect the licensing for SAP ECC, as it may require additional SAP licenses. The other SAP products listed (Solution Manager, PI, SCM) are not mentioned as being affected by changing the size of virtual machines in the case study.
looks correct

questions.answer_description:
Scenario: Increase the performance of SAP ECC applications by moving to SAP HANA.
References:
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/pricing/details/virtual-machines/rhel-sap-hana/
questions.question_text:
You are evaluating the migration plan.
Licensing for which SAP product can be affected by changing the size of the virtual machines?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
SAPRouter is an SAP network component that acts as an intermediary between your SAP systems and the SAP support infrastructure. It helps in securely connecting your SAP systems to the SAP support backbone, enabling SAP support to access your systems remotely and provide necessary support.

Selected Answer: D
saprouter

Selected Answer: D
saprouter

Selected Answer: D
Must be D - SAPRouter
SAP Support connects to your system via saprouter (R3 Support Connection).
Question ist "Ensure that SAP can provide technical support". Can only be done when SAP is able to connect to your system
- Forgot to vote for D

Must be D - SAPRouter
SAP Support connects to your system via saprouter (R3 Support Connection).
Question ist "Ensure that SAP can provide technical support". Can only be done when SAP is able to connect to your system.

it states "Ensure that SAP can provide technical support" and for that you need sap Router. (https://support.sap.com/en/tools/connectivity-tools/saprouter.html)
It is NOT SAP LaMa because it has different functionality
LaMa functionality:
Stopping and (re)starting SAP, as well as the underlying VM’s.
SAP Kernel upgrades.
Diagnostic agent installation
Installation of an additional Application Server instance (to an existing system)
System Copy, Clone and refresh
SAP HANA replication
SAP HANA processes
A.LaMa is logical ans

questions.question_text:
You need to ensure that you can receive technical support to meet the technical requirements.
What should you deploy to Azure?

choices.B: Migrate the SQL Server databases to Azure SQL Data Warehouse
choices.D: Deploy non-production landscapes to Azure DevTest Labs
choices.C: Deallocate virtual machines when not in use
choices.A: Configure scaling of Azure App Service

questions.answer_description:
Relevant use cases Dev/test environments for SAP workloads on Azure.
Noncritical SAP nonproduction workloads (such sandbox, development, test, and quality assurance).
Noncritical SAP business workloads.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/example-scenario/apps/sap-dev-test

discussion.content: Not correct. For me answer is C. I have many vm on azure and we desallocate vm for reduce the cost.

comments.content: Option C, deallocating virtual machines when not in use, is a valid cost-saving solution, but it does not provide the additional benefits of Azure DevTest Labs, such as policy-based management, self-service deployment, and easy sharing of environments.
just one moment: question is about nonProd env in our landscape only, i am do not sure about p.C for 100%
if you do not want to bother about azdevop implementing, then ans is C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Not sure in D, however it is valid SAP scenario mentioned by the Ms documentation.
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/solutions/sap/azure-solutions

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D
 Option C, deallocating virtual machines when not in use, is a valid cost-saving solution, but it does not provide the additional benefits of Azure DevTest Labs, such as policy-based management, self-service deployment, and easy sharing of environments.

By using Azure DevTest labs you can do the same functionality as mentioned by option C i,e deallocation of resources when not in use.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devtest-labs/devtest-lab-overview
D for me
For me: correct
